user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtTest_AddCommon:
```c
void UtTest_AddCommon(void (*Test)(void), void (*Setup)(void), void (*Teardown)(void), const char *TestName,
                      uint32 EntryType)
{
    UtTestDataBaseEntry_t UtTestDataBaseEntry;

    memset(&UtTestDataBaseEntry, 0, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry));
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Test     = Test;
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Setup    = Setup;
    UtTestDataBaseEntry.Teardown = Teardown;
    if (TestName != NULL)
    {
        strncpy(UtTestDataBaseEntry.TestName, TestName, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry.TestName) - 1);
    }

    UT_BSP_Lock();
    UtList_Add(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr, &UtTestDataBaseEntry, sizeof(UtTestDataBaseEntry_t), EntryType);
    UT_BSP_Unlock();
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtTest_AddCommon:
typedef struct
{
    void (*Test)(void);
    void (*Setup)(void);
    void (*Teardown)(void);

    /* Note - the name entry should be long enough to support a GroupName.TestName pattern,
     * hence why it uses double the OS_MAX_API_NAME length */
    char TestName[OS_MAX_API_NAME * 2];
} UtTestDataBaseEntry_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only the two calls above invoke functions from <string.h> and therefore are relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. Other lines in the function do not call string.h functions (assignments to function-pointer members, the if (TestName != NULL) check, UT_BSP_Lock/Unlock, and the UtList_Add call) and thus cannot directly violate this specific rule. The local declaration of the UtTestDataBaseEntry variable and the subsequent non-string assignment statements do not perform buffered string accesses and so are not relevant to Rule 21.17. (Any concerns about UtList_Add's use of the local object or other non-<string.h> APIs are outside the scope of Rule 21.17.)
